Description: Body sherd of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; from top: part of dog tooth pattern in added white with added red blobs; red band between two white bands; frieze of blanks filled with rectangles; red band; trace of possible white floral pattern; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of horse-riding scene (hindquarters and part of body of horse with red patches on rump and side; rider’s bottom in red) to right; cross square filled with dots as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos places the sherd in the Mature Animal Style however, human beings are not depicted on Chian pottery quite so early. She also wrongly identifies the animal as a boar. This chalice is one of the earliest examples of black-figure decoration on Chian Grand Style vases. For the interior decoration, compare British Museum 1924,1201.297.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 260, no. 516)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0870) (phase 2)
